do you see openai's master plan? app store is just the beginning.  you all are writing tool integrations for the ultimate gpt - a single model that reads your doc, chains apps on the fly, and enacts change on the world.  the end game is just one - an everything app. coming soon. what's brilliant about this is that the more apps the community builds, the faster we are all helping openai reach the ultimate gpt.   openai's ability expands as the app store expands.  let that sink in.

if you're into graphs, random walks, you might want to check out this cool paper by . he uses stochastic calculus to define a new metric on directed graphs that captures how far apart two nodes are in terms of their random walk behavior

excited to share our new oral (top 2%) paper!  we study why (eg clip) acts like bag-of-words + how to fix it.  tldr: contrastive learning issues ‚û°Ô∏è models don't know if "horse is eating grass" or "grass is eating horse" ü§Ø   üßµ we created the aro (attribution, relation + order) benchmark to evaluate fine-grained composition understanding of ai.   all the models fared poorly.   they think of the same image even if you shuffle the nouns, adj + verbs in the caption. 2/4 the issue is that standard contrastive learning is too coarse to teach the ai fine-grained compositional understanding.   we show that contrast on suitable *hard negatives* helps a lot.   great work led by üôè 3/4 code:   also check out 's really nice blog about this work!

we are less than a week from the virtual hackathon for applications in materials science and chemistry. here is some inspiration from other's applications to drive you!  üóìÔ∏è register and start teaming today:    chatgpt can also be used for applications in drug discovery. shared via who is also a hackathon co-organizer and judge.   paper-qa, question and answering software to answer specific questions from pdfs .  embed docs into vectors -> embed query into vector -> search for top k passages in docs   fan li shows zotero qa which attaches summarization and qa capabilities to your zotero library.  group hackathon projects using for more llm inspiration.  chemnlp is a new open community effort collecting chemistry datasets and exploring llm applications in chemistry. you can join the discord today, and start collaborating with the community.   bionemo by is a cloud service for generative ai in drug discovery that leverages llms and other capabilities like alphafold.  scholarbert, a science focused bert model trained on 221b tokens from scientific corpus, openly available on .   ü§ó link:   ethan mollick shows an example using bing to design some trendy new watches. really, you could just scroll through 's entire timeline for llm application inspiration. üòÑ   üí° let's build some amazing llm applications in materials and chemistry together‚ú®  slack invite is on the event page once you register. and here‚Äôs another application from today!

we took chatgpt offline monday to fix a bug in an open source library that allowed some users to see titles from other users‚Äô chat history. our investigation has also found that 1.2% of chatgpt plus users might have had personal data revealed to another user. 1/2 we believe the number of users whose data was actually revealed to someone else is extremely low and we have contacted those who might be impacted. we take this very seriously and are sharing details of our investigation and plan here. 2/2

a comprehensive survey of ai-generated content (aigc): a history of generative ai from gan to chatgpt  a great survey that provides a comprehensive overview of generative models, common models(unimodals, multimodals), and recent advances in generative ai.

ai development ecosystems are increasingly complex and challenging to maintain. companies like meta need to develop highly efficient systems to build, serve and improve ai models for production uses.  here's how we make this work effective + efficient ‚¨áÔ∏è

building a chatgpt-like llm might be easier than anyone thought. at , we tuned a 2-year-old open source model to follow instructions in just 3 hours, and are open sourcing the code. we think this tech will quickly be democratized. this work built on the open source 6-billion parameter gpt-j model from , with the training data and method from 's alpaca and and co's self-instruct. the surprising thing is that the original gpt-j model is 2 years old and trained without the latest architectural changes, without a ton of data curation (just on the pile), not much code, no reinforcement learning, etc. just pile + tuning on 50k instruction following samples. maybe instruction is all you need? it seems to have an outsized impact vs scale and even some aspects of data selection and curation to get a usable instruction-following model. we are excited about what this means for democratizing llms and letting every org build its own. obligatory diagram for people who like circles to show how small a model can still usefully follow human instructions:

openai has all rights to stay closed. their board their decision.  but makes the right point. they've been spreading like wild fire. the stakes are too high now.   if things do go south, we will need more than just openai containing the breakout.

at&t is transforming their operations and enhancing sustainability‚Äîusing nvidia-powered ai to process data more efficiently, optimize service-fleet routing, and build digital avatars for employee support and training.

is the ai community going to see a complete disregard for openness, research, and transparency from major companies?  great article written by , really showing the problems with secrecy in the release of ai models such as gpt-4.

reinforcement learning with human feedback (rlhf) is a key component in the latest developments in llms such as chatgpt and claude.  check out this great introduction to rlhf by . it includes some examples to visually demonstrate the benefits of rlhf.

if you're an ambitious engineering student and you're wondering what to work on to advance your career, you're asking the wrong question. work on whatever you're most excited about; if you're ambitious, your excitement will outweigh the hotness of the field you choose. this is a somewhat self-correcting answer, because ambitious engineering students naturally tend to be attracted to promising fields. in fact, it's hard to imagine a better way to predict which fields are promising.

in honor of women‚Äôs history month, we look at how women are shaping the ai field in this yet-to-be released data from the . ‚ÜòÔ∏è first, good news: more women are being hired by north american universities for tenure-track cs positions. since 2017, the proportion of new female cs faculty hires increased from 20.8% to 30.17%. american k-12 cs education is becoming more diverse. the share of ap cs exams taken by female students increased from 16.8% in 2007 to 30.6% in 2021. however, women still make up about a quarter or less of computer science degrees at all levels, with some slight growth over the decade. faculty levels mirror this trend and have been flat over the past 10 years. the launches soon, so sign up for our newsletter to make sure you see it first:

i urge interested readers to consult the et al. in press: we find that the "grnn" lstm of et al. 2018 trained on a childhood's worth of english shows substantial success on filler‚Äìgap dependencies and the island constraints on them. 1/3 in these graphs, a filler‚Äìgap dependency's signature is "blue bars below 0, red bars above 0". islands should shrink or eliminate this pattern. grnn is trained on ~90m words of english, or a 6-to-8-year-old's amount of linguistic experience. it's as successful as gpt-3. 2/3 these results don't mean llms are entirely humanlike models of language, but in my view they call into question poverty of the stimulus in even its "weaker" form. for english filler‚Äìgap dependencies & island constraints, a childhood's worth of input is enough. 3/3

unreal how few ppl in tech know who is. cody‚Äôs three cs degrees (bs 4.9 + ms 5.0) & (phd 4.0) are perhaps the least remarkable part  born in a nj prison, his journey to become co-founder & ceo of should be known by everyone in our ecosystem! back in 2017, while pursuing his phd in computer science , walked the audience through his life‚Äôs journey. its truly one of the most inspirational stories that i‚Äôve ever heard in my entire life!  digging deeper: how a few extra moments can change lives this week & co-founders shared their collective story  meeting as cs freshmen + reconnecting after their phds to build , the huge market oppty, why unstructured visual data is hard, and the tech that makes so special! to understand why and i led this round alongside our friend check out their most recent blog post:   businesses looking to unleash the power of their unstructured visual content, sign up for a demo!

facebook is aggressively going after llama repos with dmca's. llama-dl was taken down, but that was just the beginning. they've knocked offline a few alpaca repos, and maintainers are making their huggingface mirrors private "so at least i can use it as a peresonal backup." in the near term, you should prepare for dalai going down. it seems >80% likely that fb will go after them next -- llama-dl wasn't even a quarter of the popularity. there seems to be a lag time between when a project was launched vs when it's taken down, so eta is next week. update: the creator of dalai just launched a decentralized model distribution platform.

üí° how to use chatgpt in jupyter notebook  i created a cell magic that will allow you to talk to the openai api directly from your notebook: why am i doing this?  i want to integrate ai tools into my workflow. they are revolutionary.  and the best way to do so is via reducing friction (having them available where i work).  here are a couple more observations from this project and how to install it: i went for cell magic (and not line magic) to make sending error messages to chatgpt easy: how to use it:  ‚úÖ use `ai_ask` to start a new conversation (it will reset your context) ‚úÖ use `ai_continue` to continue the earlier conversation  this should work seamlessly. you should be able to have an endless conversation. i plan to use ai tools for programming and will share my learnings along the way.  follow me if projects like this one might be of interest.  you can find ask_ai on here:

i've developed a lot of plugin systems, and the openai chatgpt plugin interface might be the damn craziest and most impressive approach i've ever seen in computing in my entire life. for those who aren't aware: you write an openapi manifest for your api, use human language descriptions for everything, and that's it. you let the model figure out how to auth, chain calls, process data in between, format it for viewing, etc. there's absolutely zero glue code.
